Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Reindigenization and in situ Conservation of Crop Diversity in the Andes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
University of Georgia doctoral student, Kristine Skarbo, with guidance from Dr. Virginia Nazarea, will undertake research on how sociocultural factors affect the way farmers maintain crop diversity. Her research will focus on the Ecuadorian Andes. The Andean region long has been a center of origin of agriculture, where farmers have domesticated and developed a wealth of varieties with distinct properties and genetic make-ups within a number of crop species. Over recent decades, this diversity has declined, in part because indigenous practices have been devalued and people have turned away from traditional foods. However, recently there have been radical shifts in political as well as social landscapes across the Andean region, sometimes referred to as "reindigenization." By recasting indigeneity in a more positive light, these developments provide a natural laboratory in which to better understand the relationship between social, cultural, and political processes and the maintenance of crop diversity.

The researcher will employ a mixture of social science research methods, including participant observation, archival research, focus group discussions, life history interviews, ethnobotanical collection, a seasonal interview survey, and comparison with a crop diversity data set collected in the study area six years earlier. These qualitative and quantitative data will allow her to assess whether the reindigenization process can be linked to changes over time in the symbolic values of food, food consumption patterns, and crop diversity.

This research is important because it will produce a detailed measurement of the region's crop diversity and how it has changed over the past six years. By also connecting this changing inventory to cultural and political changes, the research will advance social scientific understanding of the connections between the larger society, farmer management, and plant genetic resources. Thus the research will contribute to both local and global conservation and development efforts, as well as to the education of a graduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examines patterns and processes of change in agrobiodiversity in the Ecuadorian Andes, and in particular how these processes are linked to cultural and climatic change. 

Despite of the central role of agrobiodiversity in sustaining humanity’s future food supply, scientific insight into the present conservation status of crop and intracrop diversity is deficient for many geographical regions. It is clear that much genetic diversity has been lost from the world’s fields, but the severity and dynamics of this loss are not well understood.

This research addresses these issues through a case study in Cotacachi, located in the Northern Ecuadorian Andes. First, it sets out to address the lack of scientific insight into diversity’s conservation status by a detailed documentation of the area’s crop and intracrop diversity. Second, it aims at expanding understanding of dynamics in the maintenance of agrobiodiversity by investigating spatial and temporal change in diversity levels and their drivers, with a particular emphasis on the potentially significant, but poorly understood, roles of cultural identity and climate change.

The findings show that a rich diversity is cultivated in the area, encompassing 103 crop species, and 367 varieties within 20 of these. The diversity is unevenly distributed among the area’s farms, however, and much is present in very low frequencies. The research indicates that these low frequencies partly result from processes of genetic erosion in the latter decades of the 20th century, when agriculture lost its central role as a livelihood source, and rural Kichwa increasingly incorporated imported food items in their diets. On the other hand, recent cultural revitalization, linked to the rise of indigenous movements, has resulted in a new appreciation of local food traditions. Longitudinal comparison of crop diversity shows that this new awareness has partly reversed previous trends of genetic erosion. A cross-sectional analysis further reveals that a similar pattern can be identified across the present landscape; the farmers who maintain other aspects of Kichwa traditions are more likely to also grow higher levels of crop and intracrop diversity, even when controlling for a number of other factors.

Recent climatic irregularity has reduced harvests and improved conditions for several agricultural pests, both processes which complicate farmers’ seed saving. Yet at the same time people draw upon their diverse seed when they adjust to the altered climate. First, farmers experiment with moving crops’ planting dates. For example, increasingly wetter summers have incited farmers to switch from growing blight-prone potatoes during this season and instead to plant rain resistant faba beans (Vicia faba). Second, in response to observations of warmer weather, farmers move heat-demanding crops further uphill, into zones where their cultivation earlier was prohibited by cold temperatures. This study in particular documented this development in the case of the locally important crop maize (Zea mays).

This research highlights the role of cultural factors in shaping farmers’ choices of crop diversity, and thus contributes to previous research on this relation (Nazarea 1998, Nazarea 2005, Perreault 2005). It extends insights from studies that have found that diversity levels vary between ethnic groups (Brush and Perales 2007; Stromberg et al. 2010), by showing that also within one ethnic group, people more firmly rooted in that group’s cultural practices tend to grow more diverse fields. Importantly, it shows that while cultural change can undermine the maintenance of agricultural biodiversity, recent cultural revitalization provides prospects for recuperating such loss.
